text.p: The following are top stories from selected Singapore newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Singapore plans new sports centres and stadia island-wide under a Singapore $360 million plan for facilities to promote healthy lifestyles.
- Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong has an active, but not rigid, routine for exercise, diet and relaxation, including tennis and golf, he tells the media.
- A Middle East peace settlement is set for early this week in Washington.
- Property agents are looking quietly for buyers for a string of commercial properties.
- The Indian government's largest trading company, State Trading Corp of India Ltd, plans to set up its first overseas subsidary in Singapore and hopes to do US$100 million in business in first year.
- Troubled Scotts Holdings forms special committe to review transactions over past few years with directors-related companies.
- In final rush to meet year-end targets and win market share, motor traders are not just slasing margins but also adopting new price-cutting tactics.
- Jardine Fleming Investment Management in Hong Kong, troubled fund management arm of Jardine Fleming, says up to US$3 billion of assets under its control are "vulnerable".
- U.S. House of Representatives passes sweeping securities deregulation measure.
- Jack Chia-MPH is on an acquisition trail, new chairman Chatri Chiarapurk says.
- Sea View Hotel reports three per cent decline in group net earnings to Singapore $3.84 million for year to June 30, 1996.
